text.headline: IBM CP-40 / CP-67 Virtual Machines
text.text: IBM develops CP-40 (later CP-67), pioneering full hardware virtualization on mainframes.

events.notes: This marks the birth of virtualization technology. IBM's research laid the foundation for all modern VMs.

text.headline: IBM VM/370
text.text: IBM releases VM/370, the first widely deployed commercial VM OS for System/370.

events.notes: VM/370 proved virtualization could be commercially viable and became widely adopted in enterprise computing.

text.headline: Founding of VMware
text.text: VMware is founded by Diane Greene, Mendel Rosenblum and others, accelerating x86 virtualization.

events.notes: VMware brought virtualization from mainframes to commodity x86 hardware, revolutionizing the industry.

text.headline: VMware Workstation 1.0
text.text: VMware ships its first x86 virtualization product.

events.notes: First commercial x86 virtualization product, enabling developers to run multiple OSes on a single machine.

text.headline: FreeBSD Jails
text.text: FreeBSD 4.0 introduces 'jails', providing early OS-level process isolation.

events.notes: Jails pioneered OS-level virtualization, a precursor to modern container technologies like Docker.

text.headline: Public Release of Xen
text.text: Xen hypervisor publicly released, enabling paravirtualized and full virtualization on x86.

events.notes: Xen became the foundation for early cloud computing, powering Amazon EC2's initial infrastructure.

text.headline: Intel VT-x Announced
text.text: Intel introduces VT-x hardware virtualization extensions to reduce VM/host transition costs.

events.notes: Hardware-assisted virtualization dramatically improved VM performance and simplified hypervisor development.

text.headline: AMD-V Introduced
text.text: AMD releases AMD-V hardware virtualization extensions.

events.notes: AMD's virtualization extensions brought competition and wider adoption of hardware-assisted virtualization.

text.headline: KVM Merged into Linux Kernel
text.text: KVM integrated into Linux kernel v2.6.20, enabling Linux to act as a native hypervisor.

events.notes: KVM turned Linux itself into a hypervisor, making virtualization accessible to all Linux systems.

text.headline: Introduction of Linux Containers (LXC)
text.text: Linux Containers emerge through cgroups and namespaces, providing OS-level isolation.

events.notes: LXC combined kernel features to create lightweight containers, setting the stage for Docker.

text.headline: Docker Public Launch
text.text: Docker introduces a modern workflow for application containers using layered images.

events.notes: Docker revolutionized software deployment with easy-to-use containers, images, and registries.

text.headline: Terraform 0.1 Release
text.text: Terraform introduces cloud-vendor-agnostic infrastructure-as-code.

events.notes: Terraform enabled declarative, multi-cloud infrastructure management using HCL configuration files.

text.headline: AWS Lambda Launches (Serverless Debut)
text.text: AWS Lambda introduces serverless computing—event-driven execution without servers.

events.notes: Lambda pioneered serverless computing, abstracting infrastructure entirely from developers.

text.headline: HashiCorp Packer 1.0
text.text: Packer reaches 1.0, automating VM, cloud image, and container image creation.

events.notes: Packer standardized machine image creation across multiple platforms from a single configuration.

text.headline: HashiCorp Nomad 0.1
text.text: Nomad introduces flexible cluster scheduling for both VMs and containers.

events.notes: Nomad provided a simpler alternative to Kubernetes for workload orchestration.

text.headline: Google Cloud Functions GA
text.text: Google Cloud Functions reaches GA, expanding serverless to multi-cloud ecosystems.

events.notes: Google's serverless offering helped establish serverless as a cross-cloud standard.

text.headline: Research: History of VMs & Containers
text.text: The Ideal Versus the Real – Revisiting the History of Virtual Machines and Containers published.

events.notes: Academic survey examining the evolution and convergence of virtualization technologies.

text.headline: Firecracker MicroVMs Introduced
text.text: AWS releases Firecracker for lightweight, secure microVMs powering serverless workloads.

events.notes: Firecracker combines VM security with container-like startup speed for serverless platforms.

text.headline: Crossplane 1.0 Release
text.text: Crossplane turns Kubernetes into a universal cloud control plane for multi-cloud IaC.

events.notes: Crossplane extended Kubernetes to manage cloud resources declaratively.

text.headline: Performance: Containers vs VMs
text.text: arXiv 2401.07539 reports up to 50% performance gains when running containers on bare-metal vs VMs.

events.notes: Research quantifying the performance overhead of virtualization layers.

text.headline: Real-Time: Containers vs Unikernels vs VMs
text.text: Analysis shows unikernels and microVMs rival containers for predictable latency.

events.notes: Comparative study of latency characteristics across different isolation technologies.

text.headline: Virtualization vs Containerization Study
text.text: Study comparing hypervisors, containers, microVMs, and energy use in edge & cloud environments.

events.notes: Comprehensive comparison including energy efficiency metrics for sustainable computing.

text.headline: Hybrid Container + Unikernel Strategies
text.text: Research proposes hybrid container/unikernel architectures for IoT and edge deployments.

events.notes: Exploring next-generation isolation combining containers and unikernels.

text.headline: Container & VM Performance in Automotive
text.text: Study evaluates container and VM performance on ARM64/AMD64 for software-defined vehicle workloads.

events.notes: Applying virtualization research to emerging automotive computing requirements.

text.headline: Containerized Virtualization Efficiency
text.text: 2025 benchmark paper analyzes how container image structure impacts performance across workloads.

events.notes: Latest research on optimizing container image design for performance.
